hints_html:
Recall that \(Bx = c\) where \(x = \begin{bmatrix} a \\ b \end{bmatrix}\) and our B matrix is

\(B = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & x_{1} \\ 1 & x_{2} \\ 1 & x_{3} \end{bmatrix}\)

and

\(c = \begin{bmatrix} y_{1} \\ y_{2} \\ y_{3} \end{bmatrix}\)

To see whats going on, if you expand out these matrices, you get

\(Bx = \begin{bmatrix} a + bx_{1} \\ a + bx_{2} \\ a + bx_{3} \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} y_{1} \\ y_{2} \\ y_{3} \end{bmatrix} = c\)
hints_latex:
Recall that $Bx = c$ where $x = \begin{bmatrix} a \\ b \end{bmatrix}$
and our \emph{B} matrix is

$B = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & x_{1} \\ 1 &  x_{2} \\ 1 & x_{3} \end{bmatrix}$

and

$c = \begin{bmatrix} y_{1} \\ y_{2} \\ y_{3} \end{bmatrix}$

To see whats going on, if you expand out these matrices, you get

$Bx = \begin{bmatrix} a + bx_{1} \\ a + bx_{2} \\ a + bx_{3} \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} y_{1} \\ y_{2} \\ y_{3} \end{bmatrix} = c$
hints_raw:
Recall that <math> Bx = c </math> where <math> x = \begin{bmatrix} a \\ b \end{bmatrix}</math> and our ''B'' matrix is 

<math> B = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & x_{1} \\ 1 &  x_{2} \\ 1 & x_{3} \end{bmatrix}</math>

and 

<math> c = \begin{bmatrix} y_{1} \\ y_{2} \\ y_{3} \end{bmatrix}</math>

To see whats going on, if you expand out these matrices, you get

<math>
Bx = \begin{bmatrix} a + bx_{1} \\ a + bx_{2} \\ a + bx_{3} \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} y_{1} \\ y_{2} \\ y_{3} \end{bmatrix} = c
</math>
question: 5 (a)
sols_html:
\[\begin{aligned} B^TB\mathbf{x} = B^T\mathbf{c} \Rightarrow \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 & 1 \\ 2 & 3 & 5 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 3 \\ 1 & 5 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} a \\ b \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 & 1 \\ 2 & 3 & 5 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ 4 \\ 6 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

or, in other words,

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 10 \\ 10 & 38 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} a \\ b \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 12 \\ 46 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

So the augmented matrix is

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 10 & | & 12 \\ 10 & 38 & | & 46 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

The vector \(\mathbf{c} = [2,4,6]^T\) is projected to the colum space of the matrix B (ColB) which is the plane spanned by the column vectors of B, namely

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} \quad \text{and} \quad \begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \\ 5 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]
statement_html:
You wish to fit the line y(x)=ax+b to the data points

\[\begin{aligned} (x_1,y_1)=(2,2), \quad (x_2,y_2)=(3,4), \quad (x_3,y_3)=(5,6).\end{aligned}\]

Write down the normal equations (check formula sheet if you do not remember) for the least squares approximation of the parameter vector \(\mathbf{x}=\begin{bmatrix}a\\b\end{bmatrix}\) to the data. Then, write down the augmented matrix that corresponds to these equations one would use to compute the least squares approximation of a,b (but you don’t need to compute a,b). Describe the least squares projection as a projection in three space onto a plane; specifically which vector is being projected onto which plane.

Formula sheet

The least squares ``best solution``to \(B\vec{x} = \vec{c}\) is given by the ``normal equations``\(B^TB\vec{x} = B^T\vec{c}\).

need to compute a,b). Describe the least squares projection as a
projection in three space onto a plane; specifically which vector is
being projected onto which plane.

\textbf{Formula sheet}

The least squares ``best solution``to $B\vec{x} = \vec{c}$ is given by
the ``normal equations``$B^TB\vec{x} = B^T\vec{c}$.

You wish to fit the line y(x)=ax+b to the data points

:<math>
(x_1,y_1)=(2,2), \quad (x_2,y_2)=(3,4), \quad (x_3,y_3)=(5,6).
</math>

Then, write down the augmented matrix that corresponds to these equations one would use to compute the least squares approximation of a,b (but you don't need to compute a,b). '''Formula sheet'''

The least squares ``best solution``to <math>B\vec{x} = \vec{c}</math> is given by the ``normal equations``<math> B^TB\vec{x} = B^T\vec{c}</math>.
